articleContent.title: Chord: 11th in F (Shape: A)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: 11th in F (Shape: A)

## Brief Overview
The 11th chord in F played in the A shape is a rich and colorful chord voicing that adds a lot of depth and character to musical compositions. It consists of the root (F), major third (A), perfect fifth (C), dominant seventh (E), and the 11th tone (B♭). This chord is commonly used in jazz, funk, and R&B genres and provides a unique and modern sound that can add sophistication to harmonies.

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: F
- Major Third: A
- Perfect Fifth: C
- Dominant Seventh: E
- 11th: B♭

Intervals:
- 1st to 3rd: Major 3rd (A is 4 half steps above F)
- 1st to 5th: Perfect 5th (C is 7 half steps above F)
- 1st to 7th: Dominant 7th (E is 10 half steps above F)
- 1st to 11th: Perfect 4th (B♭ is 15 half steps above F)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The 11th chord in F (played in the A shape) is commonly found in jazz, funk, and R&B music. It offers a modern and sophisticated sound, adding complexity and tension to chord progressions. This chord can create a lush and rich harmonic texture when used in the right context. It is often employed by musicians looking to infuse their music with a sense of depth and color.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the 11th chord in F played in the A shape:
1. "**Spain**" by Chick Corea - This jazz fusion classic makes extensive use of complex harmonies, including the 11th chord in F.
2. "**What's Going On**" by Marvin Gaye - In this R&B masterpiece, the 11th chord in F adds a soulful and emotive quality to the chord progression.
3. "**Cissy Strut**" by The Meters - This funk track showcases the use of the 11th chord in F to create a groovy and funky atmosphere.
